docs.title: ED Clinician Handbook
docs.text:
Welcome to your fast, mobile-friendly reference for induction, key guidelines, phone numbers, and referrals.

Clinical Judgement

Always use clinical judgement. Where a document lives on SharePoint, the link will take you to the internal version (you'll need to sign in if offsite).

docs.title: Referrals
docs.text:
Clinical Line Policy

The Allocation of Clinical Line Policy defines the formal process and expectations of different teams, along with specifying which specialty should accept which patient. When presentations don't fit neatly, refer to the most appropriate specialty based on Emergency Physician discretion.

View Full Policy

docs.title: General Guidelines
docs.text:
• Referral process: Once a decision is made that a patient needs admission or specialist input, a referral needs to be made to the appropriate team.
    • The default approach is to call the registrar of that team.
  • Outpatient referrals may be more appropriate than acute referrals in some cases
  • When in doubt, always discuss with a senior on the floor
  • Check availability hours before making referrals

docs.title: Dental Services
docs.text:
Limited Hours

  • Available: 0800-1700, Monday-Friday only
  • After hours: Contact Wellington for dental emergencies

docs.title: Spine Services
docs.text:
Christchurch-Based

  • Based in Christchurch
  • Time-critical cases: Can be contacted directly by ED
  • Standard cases: Refer through local orthopaedic team first

docs.title: ENT Services
docs.text:
Service Stretched

  • Available locally but service is very stretched
  • Try to limit out-of-hours referrals
  • See referral guidelines for when to refer after hours (document pending)

docs.title: Cardiology
docs.text:
Referral Pathways

Daytime hours: Contact cardiology registrar directly

Out of hours: Refer to medical registrar

24/7 Consultant available for:

  • Suspected STEMI requiring emergency PCI
  • Specialist advice in cardiac emergencies

PCI Centre

Local PCI centre is in Wellington - discuss with local cardiologist first

docs.title: Cardiothoracics
docs.text:
Tertiary Service

  • Based in Wellington
  • Always discuss with a senior before consulting

docs.title: Vascular Surgery
docs.text:
Local First

  • Tertiary centre in Wellington
  • Refer to local surgical team first - they manage many vascular presentations
  • Onward referral to tertiary vascular usually via local surgical team

docs.text:
lol jk

docs.title: Sick Leave Procedures
docs.text:
Immediate Action Required

Call as soon as you know you'll be unable to work. Early notification helps us arrange cover and maintain patient safety.

docs.title: How to Call in Sick
docs.text:
• Step 1: Call Early

    Contact as soon as you know you'll be off

    The sooner we know, the better we can arrange cover

  • Step 2: Contact Numbers

    Call the appropriate contact based on shift timing

    See contact details below

  • Step 3: Documentation

    Follow up with any required paperwork

    As per hospital policy

docs.title: Contact Information
docs.text:
Who to Call

Day ShiftsNight/Weekend Shifts

EPIC and MAU

  • Phone: See phone numbers

EPIC then contact MAU on the next working day

  • Available 24/7
  • Phone: See phone numbers

docs.title: Important Guidelines
docs.text:
Best Practices

  • Call, don't text - verbal confirmation is essential
  • Provide expected duration if known
  • Medical certificate may be required for extended absence
  • Return to work - confirm fitness before resuming duties

Fit for Work

You must be well enough to provide safe patient care. If in doubt about your fitness to work, discuss with your supervisor.

docs.title: Teaching & Learning
docs.text:
Learning Opportunities

There are many great opportunities for teaching in the ED, much of which occurs ad-hoc on the shop floor. If you have specific learning objectives for a shift, discuss with your supervising SMO and the EPIC.

docs.title: Formal Teaching Sessions
docs.text:
• Weekly ED Teaching

    Thursdays 0800 - Comprehensive morning sessions

    • Trainees: Attend for full morning
    • Other RMOs: Minimum 2 hours, then return to floor

    View Timetable

  • Radiology Meeting

    Interesting radiology cases discussion in Radiology seminar room

    Submit your interesting cases to contribute!

    Submit Case

docs.title: Calcium Calculator
docs.text:
Quick converter for calcium dosing. Enter the dose in any format (mmol, mg, or mL of either preparation) and see all equivalent doses.

Clinical Context

Two calcium formulations are commonly used in emergency medicine:

  • Calcium Gluconate 10%: 2.23 mmol Ca²⁺ (93 mg elemental) in 10 mL (0.223 mmol/mL)
  • Calcium Chloride 10%: 6.8 mmol Ca²⁺ (272 mg elemental) in 10 mL (0.68 mmol/mL)

Important: The mmol values refer to calcium ions (Ca²⁺), which is the clinically useful measure. The total compound mmol differs from the ion concentration.

Key Points

  • Calcium chloride contains ~3× more calcium ions per mL than calcium gluconate
  • Both are 10% w/v solutions (1 g of compound in 10 mL)
  • Calcium chloride is more caustic and should be given via central line when possible
  • Calcium gluconate is preferred for peripheral administration
  • The calculator accepts input in mmol Ca²⁺, mg elemental calcium, or mL of either preparation
  • Always verify doses and formulation before administration

docs.title: Magnesium Calculator
docs.text:
Quick converter for magnesium dosing. Convert between the common units used in clinical practice and calculate vials needed.

Clinical Context

MgSO₄ heptahydrate (MgSO₄·7H₂O) is the form listed in medchart, though most clinical guidelines simply refer to "magnesium" or "MgSO₄".

Standard preparation: 2 mmol/mL (10 mmol in 5 mL vial)

Key Conversions

  • 1 g MgSO₄·7H₂O ≈ 4 mmol Mg²⁺
  • % w/v = grams per 100 mL of solution
  • Always verify doses

docs.text:

These are the most commonly used ED guidelines. More hospital guidelines can be found on the main intranet.

Can't find what you're looking for?

  • Use the search function above
  • Check the full guidelines repository on SharePoint
  • Contact senior staff for guidance on uncommon presentations

docs.title: Traumatic Injuries
docs.text:
Common Injury Dispositions

Standard management and discharge planning for common traumatic injuries This list is not exhaustive or absolute. If in doubt discuss with senior ± orthopaedic team.

docs.title: Upper Limb
docs.text: Injury Management Disposition Clavicle fracture (paediatric) Polysling Discharge - GP follow up Torus fracture Wool and crepe for up to 2 weeks Discharge - no follow up Colles' fracture (stable & adequately reduced) Below elbow cast/backslab Fracture clinic follow up Scaphoid fracture (clinical/confirmed) Scaphoid cast/splint Fracture clinic follow up Radial head fracture (undisplaced) Broad arm sling Discharge - GP follow up Boxer's fracture (acceptable angulation) Buddy strap Fracture clinic follow up

docs.title: Lower Limb
docs.text: Injury Management Disposition 5<sup>th</sup> metatarsal fracture Rigid shoe/boot Discharge - GP follow up 4-6 weeks Weber A ankle fracture CAM boot or backslab Fracture clinic follow up

docs.title: Soft Tissue Injuries
docs.text: Injury Management Disposition Ankle sprain (Grade 1-2) RICE protocol, tubigrip Discharge - physio if not improving via GP / ACC Achilles tendon rupture Equinus backslab/boot (thromboprophylaxis!) Urgent ortho clinic

docs.title: Red Flags Requiring Discussion
docs.text:
Always Discuss With Orthopaedics

  • Open fractures
  • Neurovascular compromise
  • Displaced intra-articular fractures
  • Fracture-dislocations
  • Unstable ankle fractures (Weber B/C with talar shift)
  • Femoral neck fractures
